posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
Hello! For the past month, I have been working on a NetworkTables client, written from scratch using Rust! In fact, I even released version 0.2.0 (not quite a 1.0.0 release yet) just today. It includes full coverage over the NetworkTables 4.1 spec , which includes things like subscribing and publishing to topics.

The intended use for this library is within coprocessors. Writing in Rust means that you get better performance and memory usage than Java and even C++ in some cases, plus the developer experience is an extra bonus.

For some background, I started this project because I wanted an alternative to Shuffleboard. Don’t get me wrong, I think Shuffleboard is great, but it can get very slow, and the plugin system can be a hassle to work with. So I began work on a custom dashboard that runs alongside a robot program (via a bootstrap executable) that runs a webserver locally. The webserver would then be the entrypoint to interacting with the NetworkTables server. I couldn’t find many up-to-date and good implementations of the NetworkTables spec, so I decided it would be fun if I made my own!

GitHub crates.io

I would love for any of you Rust fanatics to give it a try (and find any bugs I may have missed)!

link_counts.title: GitHub - DatAsianBoi123/nt_client: A blazingly fast NetworkTables 4.1 client

posts.name: Bowan Foryt
posts.cooked:
Funny enough I’ve also made a Nt4 Server&Client in rust, although it never got to 100% maturity b4 I got distracted :< (there are some performance footguns, doesn’t support 4.1, the server is not fully compliant with spec in some minor regards and doesn’t save persistent topics)

There are many alternatives to shuffleboard already btw, Elastic is a direct successor made in flutter that has full compatibility with the shuffleboard API in robot code* . Glass and AdvantageScope are packaged with WPILib and both offer great diagnostic tools and can be used as driver dashboards kinda.

There are plans to make a web-based dashboard that’s hosted on the rio for 2027. The rio is already dying a death of a thousand cuts on the performance side and it’s not super worth it to add any more layers of indirection for data in a dashboard. If you would like to host the dashboard on the rio I would recommend using a TS/JS nt4 client to save on the on robot performance.

*shuffleboard API in robot code is incredibly slow and elastic supports local layouts so you can use any logging framework

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
Oh that’s cool, I’ve never seen that project before. It looks very similar to another one that I used before, they might’ve forked from your repo? (I’m talking about this , it isn’t forked but the example code is exactly the same?)

I guess I never really did any research on third-party dashboards, only the ones mentioned in the FRC control systems doc like smartdashboard and glass. I have heard of AdvantageScope and do want to try it out one day.

I also didn’t realize that there were plans already for a web-based dashboard in 2027. Unfortunately, I would’ve graduated by then so it won’t be too much use for me. I’m planning on hosting the server on the laptop rather than the rio to save on performance.

link_counts.title: GitHub - tsar-boomba/network-tables-rs: A implementation of WPI's Network Tables spec

posts.name: Bowan Foryt
posts.cooked:
i forked from them for the client, i still have to give proper credit but its not published yet so i havent gotten around to it. the example code needs to be deleted as it no longer works blah blah blah.

If you want to use web technologies for the GUI but run it locally i cannot recomend tauri enough, you can use your rust network tables client and it can be packaged as a standalone app. Choreo uses tauri, it is very much like electron(vscode, ascope, ppanel) on the frontend side but doesnt take a decade to open.

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: Oh yeah, I’ve heard of tauri before. Making it a standalone app would actually be easier than having to start a web server; it’s definitely something I’ll have to consider. I still have to figure out a plugin/widget system for it though, and I’m not entirely sure how I would do that with tauri. I’d have to do more research. I do want to stick with something similar to HTML/CSS though, as it’s way easier to work with and will be much easier to make plugins for. I’ve had too much trauma using JavaFX for shuffleboard plugins.

posts.name: Bowan Foryt
posts.cooked: Tauri uses WebView for the GUI aka HTML/CSS/JS and allows the GUI JS to make calls to the backend rust code. There is a project called FWC ( FRC Web Components) that has web components for most of the widgets you see in Shuffleboard.  Although i will recommend just using Elastic if you’re looking for a Shuffleboard replacement.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Gold872/elastic-dashboard: A simple and modern dashboard for FRC

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: Those projects looks really cool, will definitely take a look next time I get a chance. I really didn’t realize just how many 3rd party dashboards there are, especially ones built in Rust. Will probably try out Elastic for pre-season this year and maybe competition if I really like it.

posts.name: Bowan Foryt
posts.cooked: Elastic is in need for maintainers so… if you like it enough to learn dart you can try and picking up some issues in the github :3

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: Oh yeah definitely. I think (?) I’ve used dart before for some small mobile projects. It can’t be that hard to learn, right? And plus I gotta get my github profile looking better with those pull requests.
